https://www.foxnews.com/media/elon-musk-.title: Elon Musk congratulates SpaceX, NASA for 'excellent work' rescuing stranded astronauts
https://www.foxnews.com/media/elon-musk-.body: DOGE head and SpaceX founder Elon Musk describes his elation on 'Hannity' after two stranded astronauts returned to Earth after spending months in space.
https://www.foxnews.com/media/elon-musk-.full_content: Elon Musk offers his 'congratulations' after SpaceX rescues stranded astronauts | Fox News Recommended 17:38 Greg Gutfeld: Dems are responsible for their own demise 01:20 Tim Walz says Trump makes people feel like 'part of something' 01:35 Texas Gov. Greg Abbott says daily border crossings in El Paso have plummeted under Trump 01:43 Sunny Hostin scolds Schumer that he 'caved' on GOP spending bill 01:19 Chuck Schumer shrugs off suggestion he should step down as party leader 01:32 Rep. Moulton warns Dems need to reform, stop being party who 'preach' and 'scold' 08:56 Trump is sending a clear message to every illegal immigrant: Judge Jeanine 07:13 Sean Hannity: The Democratic Party is officially a dumpster fire 05:33 'Seen and Unseen': Dems need a moment to figure out their messaging 08:15 Comedian Andrew Schulz on the Statue of Liberty and 'conquering' Greenland 00:30 Border czar Homan schools reporter for referring to Alien Enemies Act as 'old law,' cites U.S. Constitution 01:49 'The View' co-hosts blast Schumer for voting to avert shutdown, promise to grill him during upcoming interview 04:50 DOJ lawyer denounces her firing over handling of Mel Gibson gun case 01:32 Randi Weingarten tells MSNBC she's 'spitting mad' over Education Department staffing cuts 01:43 Jasmine Crockett hits back at criticism of viral 'choose your fighter' video of Dems 05:02 Elon is Trump's 'heat shield' against government cuts, Democratic strategist says 08:30 'Overvalued' markets were 'due for a correction' following Trump's tariffs: Caroline Downey 08:28 Mahmoud Khalil shows 'no evidence' of Hamas support, Glenn Greenwald says 01:28 MSNBC panel unloads on Sen. Chuck Schumer over support for GOP spending bill 01:15 CNN‚Äôs Van Jones says Dems unleashing ‚Äòvolcanic anger‚Äô towards Schumer for caving on spending bill close Video Elon Musk celebrates 'moment of optimism' after NASA astronauts' return to Earth on SpaceX Elon Musk congratulates SpaceX team for 'excellent work' in bringing home the stranded astronauts, addresses 'domestic terrorism' against his company for his association with Trump and more on 'Hannity.' Billionaire and tech titan Elon Musk shared his congratulations to SpaceX and NASA following the rescue of two astronauts stranded at the International Space Station for roughly the past nine months. "Thanks to the excellent work of the SpaceX team working with NASA, the astronauts are now safely home. And so congratulations to the SpaceX NASA teams on excellent work," Musk said during an exclusive interview on "Hannity" Tuesday. The SpaceX founder and face of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) also offered a "huge note of appreciation" to President Donald Trump "for prioritizing and expediting the return." SPACEX DRAGON CAPSULE STICKS SPLASHDOWN LANDING AS NASA ASTRONAUTS RETURN HOME AFTER MONTHS STUCK IN SPACE Astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams had been on the International Space Station since June 2024. Their mission was only scheduled to last one week after the launch of Boeing's first astronaut flight. However, after the spacecraft encountered technical issues, and NASA determined it unsafe for it to arrive back to Earth with the astronauts on board, Wilmore and Williams remained stuck at the International Space Station for months. Wilmore, Williams, Crew-9 Commander Nick Hague and Russian cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov made their return to Earth on Tuesday, with a splashdown off the coast of Florida just before 6 p.m. ET. Video Wilmore and Williams' return became a political issue for the Trump administration, with Musk previously telling Fox News host Sean Hannity on Feb. 18 that former President Joe Biden left the astronauts in space for "political reasons." Shortly after taking office, Trump tasked Musk with bringing home the two astronauts, who he said had been "abandoned" by the Biden administration. Video STRANDED ASTRONAUT SAYS HE BELIEVES MUSK'S CLAIMS THAT BIDEN REFUSED TO CONDUCT RESCUE MISSION Trump also blasted Biden for not acting sooner. "I have just asked Elon Musk and @SpaceX to ‚Äògo get‚Äô the 2 brave astronauts who have been virtually abandoned in space by the Biden Administration. They have been waiting for many months on @Space Station. Elon will soon be on his way. Hopefully, all will be safe. Good luck Elon!!!" posted Trump at the time . Video In a post-landing news conference with SpaceX and NASA officials on Tuesday, Deputy Associate Administrator, NASA Space Operations Mission Directorate Joel Montalbano was asked about Trump and Musk's claims that the Biden administration didn't want to bring the Starliner crew back for political reasons. Video "Yeah, so I wasn't involved in any conversations with the previous administration," Montalbano said. "It was clear we had a request from the current administration, and the results you saw are what we saw today with the landing of Crew-9." CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP Hannity pressed Musk on the politics behind the astronauts' delayed return, and Musk set the record straight on his communications with the previous Biden administration. "We definitely offered to return the astronauts earlier. There's no question about that," Musk said. "The astronauts were only supposed to be there for eight days, and they've been there for almost ten months. So, obviously, that doesn't make any sense. SpaceX could have brought the astronauts back after a few months at most, and we made that offer to the Biden administration. It was rejected for political reasons, and that's just a fact." Fox News' Jonathan Serrie, Landon Mion, Diana Stancy, Christina Shaw and Reuters contributed to this report. Madeline Coggins is a Digital Production Assistant on the Fox News flash team with Fox News Digital. https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/other/wh.title: Why Oracle Could Be Key to a TikTok Deal
https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/other/wh.body: TikTok parent company ByteDance Ltd. is once again racing toward a deadline to sell off its popular video app or face a ban in the US. Several interested buyers have publicly emerged, and the most discussed deal scenarios involve a key role for a longtime partner of the video platform: Oracle Corp.

https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/o.title: OpenAI is pushing for Donald Trump to weaken copyright protections in the US. Paul McCartney is fighting back.
https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/o.body: Letter signed by 400 creative types, including a Beatle, issued after startling submission to US government by OpenAI and Google.
https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/o.full_content: OpenAI is pushing for Donald Trump to weaken copyright protections in the US. Paul McCartney is fighting back. March 19, 2025 By Tim Ingham Pic credits: Shutterstock OpenAI founder Sam Altman finds himself up against Sir Paul McCartney in the battle to convince US lawmakers over copyright laws and artificial intelligence The maker of ChatGPT, OpenAI, has called for fundamental changes to US copyright law that would allow AI companies to use copyrighted works without permission or compensation to rightsholders. Continue to article... That‚Äôs according to a fresh policy submission to the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP). The document does not make happy reading for copyright holders, which explains why music stars like Sir Paul McCartney, Paul Simon, and Bette Midler have joined hundreds of Hollywood celebrities in signing a letter pushing back against the proposals. The submission, filed by OpenAI on March 13 ( read it in full here ), is part of the tech company‚Äôs response to the Trump administration‚Äôs request for information on developing a national AI Action Plan . Both OpenAI and Google submitted detailed policy frameworks that could significantly impact music rightsholders and other content creators. These submissions represent high-stakes policy positioning as the Trump administration develops its AI Action Plan, which could fundamentally shape how creative works are protected √¢¬Ä¬î or not protected √¢¬Ä¬î in the rapidly evolving AI ecosystem. OpenAI Calls for Unrestricted AI Training Access In its March 13 submission, OpenAI heavily focuses on the concept of ‚Äúfair use‚Äù √¢¬Ä¬ì i.e. platforms being able to use copyright in certain circumstances without punishment. The firm explicitly argues that applying the ‚Äòfair use‚Äô doctrine to AI in the United States is ‚Äúnot only a matter of American competitiveness √¢¬Ä¬î it‚Äôs a matter of national security‚Äù ,√Ç while warning that without it having free access to copyrighted materials, ‚Äúthe race for AI is effectively over‚Äù . In OpenAI‚Äôs eyes, China will win that race if the US doesn‚Äôt loosen its copyright laws. ‚ÄúIf [China‚Äôs] developers have unfettered access to data and American companies are left without fair use access , the race for AI is effectively over. America loses , as does the success of democratic AI.‚Äù OpenAI submission The relevant quote from the OpenAI submission reads: ‚ÄúApplying the fair use doctrine to AI is not only a matter of American competitiveness √¢¬Ä¬î it‚Äôs a matter of national security . The rapid advances seen with the PRC [People‚Äôs Republic Of China]‚Äôs DeepSeek , among other recent developments, show that America‚Äôs lead on frontier AI is far from guaranteed.‚Äù OpenAI adds: ‚ÄúGiven concerted state support for critical industries and infrastructure projects, there‚Äôs little doubt that the PRC‚Äôs AI developers will enjoy unfettered access to data √¢¬Ä¬î including copyrighted data √¢¬Ä¬î that will improve their models. ‚ÄúIf the PRC‚Äôs developers have unfettered access to data and American companies are left without fair use access , the race for AI is effectively over. America loses , as does the success of democratic AI.‚Äù OpenAI‚Äôs submission further states: ‚ÄúAmerican copyright law, including the longstanding fair use doctrine, protects the transformative uses of existing works, ensuring that innovators have a balanced and predictable framework for experimentation and entrepreneurship.‚Äù Did OpenAI just give a gift to music‚Äôs lobbyists? Passages in √Ç OpenAI‚Äôs √Ç submission could be interpreted as acknowledging that√Ç current US copyright law restricts the company‚Äôs desired activities, though the√Ç language is somewhat ambiguous. One notable section is where OpenAI states: ‚ÄúIf the PRC‚Äôs developers have unfettered access to data and American companies are left without fair use access, the race for AI is effectively over.‚Äù The wording of the phrase ‚Äúif American companies are left without fair use access‚Äù implies that AI companies in the US might need specific new ‚Äòfair use‚Äô protections drafted to continue using copyrighted materials. In turn, that could be interpreted as recognition that without such clear protections √¢¬Ä¬ì i.e. under today‚Äôs laws √¢¬Ä¬ì their activities might be legally questionable. Google Aligns with OpenAI on Copyright Stance Google‚Äôs submission ( read it in full here ) echoes similar sentiments, though with slightly less alarmist language. The search giant argues that ‚Äúbalanced copyright rules, such as fair use and text-and-data mining exceptions , have been critical to enabling AI systems to learn from prior knowledge and publicly available data, unlocking scientific and social advances.‚Äù √¢¬Ä¬úWe support America√¢¬Ä¬ôs existing fair use framework, and we√¢¬Ä¬ôre confident that current copyright law enables AI innovation.√¢¬Ä¬ù Google spokesperson The company adds that these exceptions ‚Äúallow for the use of copyrighted, publicly available material for AI training without significantly impacting rightsholders and avoid often highly unpredictable, imbalanced, and lengthy negotiations with data holders during model development or scientific experimentation.‚Äù It warns that copyright laws could, under certain interpretations, ‚Äúimpede appropriate access to data necessary for training leading models‚Äù. Subsequent to the submission being filed, a Google spokesperson said in a statement, √¢¬Ä¬úWe support America√¢¬Ä¬ôs existing fair use framework, and we√¢¬Ä¬ôre confident that current copyright law enables AI innovation.√¢¬Ä¬ù The McCartney response Stars from the world of film, TV, and music have signed a letter in response to the OpenAI and Google proposals, including Cate Blanchett, Cynthia Erivo, Paul McCartney, Paul Simon, Ron Howard, Taika Waititi, Chris Rock, Ben Stiller, Mark Ruffalo, Guillermo del Toro , and Ava Duvernay. In their letter to the US government this week, the copyright-makers state, ‚ÄúWe firmly believe that America√¢¬Ä¬ôs global AI leadership must not come at the expense of our essential creative industries.‚Äù They add that the US arts and entertainment industry provides more than 2.3 million jobs√Ç and ‚Äú provides the foundation for√Ç American democratic influence and soft power abroad .‚Äù The letter continues: √¢¬Ä¬ú[AI] companies are asking to undermine this economic and cultural strength by weakening copyright protections for the films, television series, artworks, writing, music, and voices used to train AI models at the core of multi-billion dollar corporate valuations.√¢¬Ä¬ù You can read the letter √¢¬Ä¬ì signed by 400 famous creators √¢¬Ä¬ì in full below: Hello Friends & Strangers. As you may be aware there has recently been a recommendation by OpenAI & Google to the current US Administration that is gaining alarming traction to remove all legal protections & existing guardrails surrounding copyright law protections for the training of Artificial Intelligence. This rewriting of established law in favor of so-called √¢¬Ä¬úFair Use√¢¬Ä¬ù was in need of an initial response by 11:59 PM ET Saturday, so we have submitted an initial letter with the signatories we had at that time. We are now continuing to accept signatures for an amendment to our initial statement. Please feel free to forward this to anyone you think may be invested in the ethical maintenance of their intellectual property. You can add your name and whatever guilds or unions or description of self you feel appropriate, but please do not edit the letter itself. Thank you so much for kicking this out wide on a Saturday Night! Hollywood√¢¬Ä¬ôs Response to the Administration√¢¬Ä¬ôs Artificial Intelligence Action Plan and necessity that copyright law be upheld. We, the members of America√¢¬Ä¬ôs entertainment industry √¢¬Ä¬î representing an intersection of cinematographers, directors, producers, actors, writers, studios, production companies, musicians, composers, costume, sound & production designers, editors, gaffers, union and Academy Members, and other industrious, creative content professionals √¢¬Ä¬ì submit this unified statement in response to the Administration√¢¬Ä¬ôs request for input on the AI Action Plan. We firmly believe that America√¢¬Ä¬ôs global AI leadership must not come at the expense of our essential creative industries. America√¢¬Ä¬ôs arts and entertainment industry supports over 2.3M American jobs with over $229Bn in wages annually, while providing the foundation for American democratic influence and soft power abroad. But AI companies are asking to undermine this economic and cultural strength by weakening copyright protections for the films, television series, artworks, writing, music, and voices used to train AI models at the core of multi-billion dollar corporate valuations. Make no mistake: this issue goes well beyond the entertainment industry, as the right to train AI on all copyright-protected content impacts all of America√¢¬Ä¬ôs knowledge industries. When tech and AI companies demand unfettered access to all data and information, they√¢¬Ä¬ôre not just threatening movies, books, and music, but the work of all writers, publishers, photographers, scientists, architects, engineers, designers, doctors, software developers and all other professionals who work with computers and generate intellectual property. These professions are the core of how we discover, learn, and share knowledge as a society and as a nation. This issue is not just about AI leadership or about economics and individual rights, but about America√¢¬Ä¬ôs continued leadership in creating and owning valuable intellectual property in every field. It is clear that Google (valued at $2Tn) and OpenAI (valued at over $157Bn) are arguing for a special government exemption so they can freely exploit America√¢¬Ä¬ôs creative and knowledge industries, despite their substantial revenues and available funds. There is no reason to weaken or eliminate the copyright protections that have helped America flourish. Not when AI companies can use our copyrighted material by simply doing what the law requires: negotiating appropriate licenses with copyright holders √¢¬Ä¬î just as every other industry does. Access to America√¢¬Ä¬ôs creative catalog of films, writing, video content, and music is not a matter of national security. They do not require a government-mandated exemption from existing U.S. copyright law. America didn√¢¬Ä¬ôt become a global cultural powerhouse by accident. Our success stems directly from our fundamental respect for IP and copyright that rewards creative risk-taking by talented and hardworking Americans from every state and territory. For nearly 250 years, U.S. copyright law has balanced creator√¢¬Ä¬ôs rights with the needs of the public, creating the world√¢¬Ä¬ôs most vibrant creative economy. We recommend that the American AI Action Plan uphold existing copyright frameworks to maintain the strength of America√¢¬Ä¬ôs creative and knowledge industries, as well as American cultural influence abroad. Music Business Worldwide Analysis United States MBW Explains Related Posts 5 key arguments from UMG‚Äôs attempt to dismiss Drake‚Äôs defamation lawsuit: ‚ÄòThese claims are no more than Drake‚Äôs attempt to save face.‚Äô Sony generated $2.70 billion from recorded music and publishing in calendar Q4, as ATEEZ topped firm‚Äôs global sales chart Using copyrighted content to train AI without permission is not √¢¬Ä¬òfair use√¢¬Ä¬ô, US court rules in Thomson Reuters case Can AI-generated content be copyrighted? Here√¢¬Ä¬ôs what a new report from the US Copyright Office says‚Ä¶ The best of MBW, plus the most important music biz stories on the web. Delivered for FREE, direct to your inbox each day. https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/27/stripe.title: Stripe finalizes tender sale at a $91.5B valuation, says payment volumes grew to $1.4T in 2024
https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/27/stripe.body: Digital payments platform Stripe has yet to lay out plans to go public, but in the meantime the company has thrown past and present employees a line for
https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/27/stripe.full_content: Stripe finalizes tender sale at a $91.5B valuation, says payment volumes grew to $1.4T in 2024 | TechCrunch Stripe finalizes tender sale at a $91.5B valuation, says payment volumes grew to $1.4T in 2024 | TechCrunch Image Credits: SOPA Images / Contributor / Getty Images Fintech Stripe finalizes tender sale at a $91.5B valuation, says payment volumes grew to $1.4T in 2024 Ingrid Lunden 6:32 AM PST ¬∑ February 27, 2025 Digital payments platform Stripe has yet to lay out plans to go public, but in the meantime the company has thrown past and present employees a line for some liquidity. The company on Thursday confirmed a tender offer where investors will buy up shares from those employees at a valuation of $91.5 billion. Stripe said it will also repurchase shares as part of the transaction. A spokesperson declined to say who is in the secondary round except to confirm that it is ‚Äúlargely‚Äù existing investors. Past backers of the company number at over 150 investors per PitchBook data . They include General Catalyst, GV, Silver Lake, Atomico, Elon Musk, Salesforce and many more. The tender offer is a decent jump on the company‚Äôs valuation from its last secondary sale a year ago, which was valued at $70 billion . However, Stripe still fell short of its high-watermark $95 billion valuation back in 2021. That round came at a time when e-commerce itself was booming due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and it made Stripe, at the time and only on paper, the most valuable privately-held tech company in the world. The news coincides with Stripe‚Äôs annual letter penned by CEO and co-founder Patrick Collison, which noted that payment volume in 2024 grew to $1.4 trillion, up 38% on the year before. It‚Äôs a big number for Stripe, but to put it into some context, Visa said that its payment volume for 2024 was $13.2 trillion. The margin that Stripe makes on transactions (which are what make up payment volume) remains thin, and so this business remains one where it still has room to (and needs to) scale. Stripe also added that it is now used by half of the Fortune 100 companies, underscoring how it has catapulted from a startup working with other startups, into a major enterprise player. The tender offer was originally reported to be in the works earlier this month . Topics Biotech & Health , Fintech , Fundraising , payments , secondary , stripe Ingrid Lunden Europe Editor Ingrid is a writer and editor for TechCrunch, joining February 2012, based out of London. Before TechCrunch, Ingrid worked at paidContent.org, where she was a staff writer, and has in the past also written freelance regularly for other publications such as the Financial Times. Ingrid covers mobile, digital media, advertising and the spaces where these intersect. When it comes to work, she feels most comfortable speaking in English but can also speak Russian, Spanish and French (in descending order of competence). https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/coach-ow.title: Coach's Owner Tapestry Files Trademark Infringement Suit Against Shein
https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/coach-ow.body: Like its chief fast-fashion rival Temu, Shein is facing multiple cases of trademark infringement by companies and artists.
https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/coach-ow.full_content: Coach‚Äôs Owner Tapestry Files Trademark Infringement Suit Against Shein Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Return to Homepage Don't Miss Multiple kids in small spaces 85% of centenarians are women 'Freezer library' Look at nature Health myths debunked 5-hour rule for learning Man who invented run crews Taking back your attention Cut the risk of depression 10 years of 'Hot Ones' Yahoo is using AI to generate takeaways from this article. This means the info may not always match what's in the article. Reporting mistakes helps us improve the experience. Generate Key Takeaways Tapestry‚Äôs Coach has filed a suit against the fast-fashion specialist Shein for trademark counterfeiting, federal trademark infringement, false advertising and unfair competition. The 30-page complaint was filed on Thursday in the U.S. District Court in the Central District of California by Tapestry Inc., Coach Services Inc. and Coach IP Holdings against Zoetop Business Co. and Shein U.S. Services. A juried trial is being sought. More from WWD Trump's Tariffs: The Hot-button Topic at AAFA Executive Summit in D.C. Jewelry Designer Pamela Love Sues Alex and Ani Beneficial Owners for Unpaid Consulting Fees and Sales Royalties Chanel and What Goes Around Comes Around Hear Final Judgment for Infringement Case Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement The suit alleges that Shein used commerce marks that are ‚Äúidentical or substantially indistinguishable or confusingly similar to Coach trademarks in connection with the sale, distribution and/or advertising‚Äù of the alleged counterfeit products. The allegations include that when one searches for ‚Äúcoach‚Äù on Shein‚Äôs e-commerce site, there is ‚Äúno indication‚Äù that any of the products originated from a third-party seller. When a shopper selects ‚Äúwhat appears to be legitimate ‚Äò Coach ‚Äô product for purchase, the third-party seller‚Äôs information is so small and inconspicuous that the shopper could ‚Äúreasonably believe‚Äù that Shein was the seller with title or possession of the product. Attorneys for Tapestry and Coach did not respond immediately Tuesday afternoon to requests for comment, nor did an attorney for Shein. Representatives at both companies also had not returned media requests as of Tuesday afternoon. Designer dupes and fake fashion items are an ongoing issue for major brands. Nearly seven in 10 consumers were deceived into buying counterfeit products online at least once in 2023, according to research by Michigan State University‚Äôs College of Communication Arts and Sciences. Less than two years ago, the U.S. Congress passed the Integrity, Notification and Fairness in Online Retail Marketplaces for Consumers Act to better inform consumers about third-party sellers and to reduce the number of fake and stolen goods that are sold online. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement The complaint features multiple pages with photographs of the alleged counterfeit Coach products including tote bags, handbags, shoes, hats and purses. Tapestry alleges that Shein made, marketed and sold knockoff items that used the Coach name, logos, hardware and signature ‚ÄúC‚Äù designs. The products highlighted in the legal complaint were items that were sold through Shein‚Äôs marketplace platform, which allows third-party users to post product listings. Describing the ‚Äúworld of Chinese marketplaces‚Äù as a bit like the wild west, Neil Saunders, managing director for retail at GlobalData, said ‚Äúit is hardly surprising that Tapestry wants to use the law as a taming influence. The complaint is legitimate inasmuch as Coach dupes are sold on Shein, and it‚Äôs almost impossible for the consumer to understand exactly what they‚Äôre buying. That‚Äôs detrimental to the Coach brand.‚Äù While it remains to be seen how the courts ‚Äúinterpret the technicalities of the law as the goods are sold by third parties rather than directly by Shein,‚Äù Saunders said, ‚ÄúCoach is trying to hold Shein fully liable. If they win, it will be a big victory for brands and will force Shein to take tough action on dupes and counterfeits.‚Äù Like its archrival in the fast-fashion sector Temu, Shein is facing multiple suits that have been brought forward by established brands and little-known artists for trademark infringement and counterfeit goods. The Tapestry-Shein legal action comes at a time when President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration is trying to stop ultra-cheap imports from entering the U.S. without tariffs. https://markets.businessinsider.com/news.title: Palantir Partners with Databricks in a Move That Shakes the AI Industry
https://markets.businessinsider.com/news.body: Overall, Palantir (PLTR) has had a solid start to 2025. Its growth numbers look impressive, and its AI platform is gaining traction across
https://markets.businessinsider.com/news.full_content: Palantir Partners with Databricks in a Move That Shakes the AI Industry | Markets Insider Search markets Search icon A magnifying glass. It indicates, "Click to perform a search". Close icon Two crossed lines that form an 'X'. It indicates a way to close an interaction, or dismiss a notification. Home Stocks Alphabet -stock News for Alphabet Palantir Partners with Databricks in a Move That Shakes the AI Industry Palantir Partners with Databricks in a Move That Shakes the AI Industry TipRanks Mar. 18, 2025, 09:29 AM Overall, Palantir (PLTR) has had a solid start to 2025. Its growth numbers look impressive, and its AI platform is gaining traction across industries. Yet not everyone is convinced. Some investors still hesitate due to the stock‚Äôs high price, its history of sharp swings, insiders‚Äô selling shares , and the Pentagon declaring Budget cuts that will impact Palantir‚Äôs bottom line, as more than half of its revenue stems from defense contracts. Light Up your Portfolio with Spark: Easily identify stocks' risks and opportunities. Discover stocks' market position with detailed competitor analyses. Despite its steady rise ‚Äì its stock is up 15% year-to-date ‚Äì Palantir has yet to fully overcome analysts‚Äô doubts about its ability to maintain this pace. Nevertheless, one analyst from William Blair thinks Palantir‚Äôs recent move to partner with its foe, Databricks, is a game-changer. Palantir and Databricks Join Hands Last week, the company made a move that could change the game. Palantir partnered with Databricks, another big name in AI-driven data analytics. The two companies have often been seen as rivals, but now they‚Äôre working together to make their platforms more compatible. This isn‚Äôt a full merger of their tools, and they won‚Äôt be selling a joint product. Instead, they‚Äôre making it easier for businesses to use both systems side by side. Louie DiPalma, an analyst at William Blair, weighed in on the move, noting that while Palantir and Databricks compete in some areas, they rarely go head-to-head for contracts. The market, he said, is big enough for both. More importantly, the partnership makes sense for customers. ‚ÄúSince there are now many joint users, it makes sense for both of their data platforms to work nicely with each other,‚Äù he explained. Beyond commercial clients, the partnership could also be key in the government sector. The U.S. government recently issued an order requiring agencies to adopt better tracking systems for payments. Palantir, with its reputation for handling high-security data, stands to benefit. Working with Databricks strengthens its position as a go-to choice for agencies needing powerful AI tools. For Palantir, this partnership could be a turning point. It expands its reach, enhances its platform, and makes it more competitive against tech giants like Microsoft (MSFT) and Google (GOOGL) (GOOG) . However, the big question remains: will this be enough to finally convince skeptical investors that Palantir‚Äôs rise is just getting started? Is PLTR a Buy, Hold, or a Sell? Turning to Wall Street, Palantir is considered a Hold. The average price target for PLTR stock is $94.27 , implying a 7.92% upside potential. https://people.com/dolphins-surround-spa.title: Dolphins Surround SpaceX Capsule After Ocean Splashdown as NASA Astronauts Return to Earth: Watch!
https://people.com/dolphins-surround-spa.body: Dolphins surrounded the SpaceX capsule after it landed in the ocean on the NASA astronauts' successful journey home after nine months in space on Tuesday, March 18.
https://people.com/dolphins-surround-spa.full_content:
Human Interest
Human Interest News
Dolphins Surround SpaceX Capsule After Ocean Splashdown as NASA Astronauts Return to Earth: Watch!
Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams successfully returned back to Earth after nine months in space on Tuesday, March 18
By
Escher Walcott
Escher Walcott
Escher Walcott is a Writer/Reporter at PEOPLE, covering stories in Entertainment, Style, Human Interest.She joins having written for several popular news publications, including Glamour, Refinery29, NYLON and Evening Standard, discussing the latest fashion trends, pop culture news, and pressing social matters.
People Editorial Guidelines
Published on March 19, 2025 06:49AM EDT
Comments
Dolphins Surround Dragon Landing.
Photo:
NASA
NASA astronauts
Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams
receive a surprise welcome on their return home to Earth!
Dolphins surrounded the astronauts‚Äô capsule after landing in the ocean on their journey home after
nine months in space
on Tuesday, March 18.
In
drone footage
obtained by NASA, a pod of dolphins is seen circling the SpaceX Dragon capsule that Wilmore and Williams journeyed in alongside fellow NASA astronaut Nick Hague and Russian cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov after splashing down into the water off the Florida coast.
Another
video
posted by CNN correspondent Omar Jimenez on X showed the group of dolphins swimming near the capsule shortly after landing alongside a rescue crew in a boat heading over to check on the spacecraft.
Wilmore and Williams, who made headlines after being stranded in space, made a successful splashdown hours after SpaceX Crew-9
undocked from the International Space Station
at 1:05 a.m. ET. They landed on Earth at around 6:00 p.m. local time.
Splashdown Time! 'Stranded' Astronauts Return to Earth After 9 Months in Space
NASA
and
SpaceX
confirmed the astronauts' safe arrival on X. "Splashdown of Dragon confirmed ‚Äì welcome back to Earth, Nick, Suni, Butch, and Aleks!" SpaceX wrote.
A video shared alongside the message showed the moment the capsule splashed into the ocean with four white and orange parachutes deployed gently landing and resting upright alongside. An announcer stated, "And Splashdown! Crew 9, back on earth," followed by cheers and applause.
Dolphins Surround Dragon Landing.
NASA
Wilmore and Williams arrived at the International Space Station in June 2024. They were originally expected to stay in space for no more than 10 days, however, their return was delayed after their spacecraft encountered
mechanical issues
. The spacecraft was sent back to Earth
without them
.
On March 14, a
new crew arrived at the ISS
to start the launch of Wilmore and Williams‚Äô journey back to Earth as part of a joint SpaceX and NASA mission. The crew consisted of astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, Takuya Onishi and Roscosmos cosmonaut Kirill Peskov.
Astronaut Wears 'Alien' Mask to Greet SpaceX Crew at the International Space Station
Never miss a story ‚Äî sign up for
PEOPLE's free daily newsletter
to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.
NASA‚Äôs Johnson Space Center posted
photos
on X of Wilmore and Williams being greeted by crew members after arriving at Johnson Space Center‚Äôs Ellington Field in Houston hours after their splashdown.
‚ÄúHome sweet home üè†,‚Äù the caption read. ‚ÄúNASA‚Äôs SpaceX #Crew9 touched down at Johnson Space Center‚Äôs Ellington Field in Houston at 11:19 pm CDT, March 18, after their @Space_Station mission and successful splashdown earlier this afternoon.‚Äù
‚ÄúWelcome home, Butch, Suni, Nick, & Aleksandr!‚Äù
Close

https://www.livemint.com/news/world/spac.title: SpaceX to take humans to Mars in next 20-30 years? Elon Musk claims it's possible
https://www.livemint.com/news/world/spac.body: Elon Musk predicts humans will travel to Mars in 20-30 years, emphasising SpaceX's goal to take anyone interested. Starship, the largest rocket, is crucial for this vision and is expected to launch by the end of 2026,
https://www.livemint.com/news/world/spac.full_content:
In an exclusive interview with Sean Hannity onFox News, SpaceX founder and CEO Elon Musk said that humans will be able to travel to Mars in the next 20-30 years. ‚ÄúSpaceXwill take anyone who wants to on Mars,‚Äù he claimed.

‚ÄúWe would be able to take astronauts to Mars. In fact, we want to take anyone who goes to Mars," he said, adding, ‚Äúthat is the long-term goal of the company."

When asked how long it could take for the company to accomplish this, he said, ‚ÄúI think we could do it in 20-30 years.‚Äù

It was SpaceX's Dragon aircraft that brought NASA astronautsSunita Williamsand Butch Wilmore, along with two other astronauts, back to earth on Wednesday, after being stranded aboard the International Space Station for nine months.

In a pose shared on X, Musk congratulated the team and thanked US President for prioritising the mission.

Wilmore and Williams arrived at the ISS last June on a Boeing spacecraft with plans to spend roughly a week in space. But that brief trip turned into roughly nine months whenNASAdecided in August the pair would come home on a rival SpaceX capsule instead, due to technical issues with their Boeing vehicle.

Their saga became an international spectacle, with some media outlets dubbing them the ‚Äústranded‚Äù astronauts ‚Äî a nod to NASA‚Äôs reluctance to have them fly home in their original spacecraft.

Musk said on March 15 that its massiveStarship rocket would leave for Mars at the end of 2026 with Tesla humanoid robot Optimus onboard, adding that human landings could follow "as soon as 2029."

"Starship departs for Mars at the end of next year, carryingOptimus. If those landings go well, then human landings may start as soon as 2029, although 2031 is more likely," Musk said on his X social network.

Starship ‚Äì the world's largest and most powerful rocket ‚Äì is key to Musk's long-term vision of colonising Mars.

Standing 403 feet (123 meters) tall ‚Äì about 100 feet taller than the Statue of Liberty ‚Äì Starship is designed to eventually be fully reusable.

NASA is also awaiting a modified version of Starship as a lunar lander for its Artemis program, which aims to return astronauts to the Moon this decade.

But before SpaceX can carry out those missions, it must prove the vehicle is reliable, safe for crew, and capable of complex in-orbit refueling ‚Äì critical for deep space missions.

https://www.androidauthority.com/chatgpt.title: ChatGPT connecting to your Google Drive and Slack sounds like a remote work game-changer
https://www.androidauthority.com/chatgpt.body: ChatGPT is reportedly working on Google Drive and Slack integration with a new feature that sounds perfect for WFH.
https://www.androidauthority.com/chatgpt.full_content:
Affiliate links on Android Authority may earn us a commission.Learn more.

Published on20 hours ago

Working a desk job in 2025 looks a whole lot different than it did just a couple decades prior, and for many of us, that‚Äôs meant trading the corporate office for a home office. Cloud-based tools likeSlackandGoogle Drivehave helped teams communicate and share resources as easily across the hall as across the country, but just because all the resources you‚Äôll need to get the job done are saved to shared folders or pinned to Slack channels doesn‚Äôt mean that they‚Äôre all equally accessible. This week, we‚Äôre hearing about OpenAI‚Äôs work on a new development that could do something about just that, linking Drive and Slack toChatGPT.

The company is working on a feature dubbed ChatGPT Connectors, according to a report fromTechCrunch. This would allow the chatbot to tap into shared work resources to address user queries. The system shares relevant data with ChatGPT over an encrypted connection, hopefully satisfying firms that might be a little nervous about letting an AI engine loose in an archive of company secrets, and will respect user permissions, so when you ask ChatGPT something it will only rely upon info in folders and channels you have access to for its response.

Particularly private stuff like Slack DMs won‚Äôt be indexed by Connectors, and there are a few gaps in its skill set with shared files, not supporting images in documents, and having only a limited ability to read spreadsheet data.

Still, this sounds like it has the potential to be incredibly useful, and especially so for remote workers. ChatGPT Connector hooked up to Google Drive and Slack could become the stand-in for that employee everyone‚Äôs always turning to for answers about policies, or best practices, able to instantly tap into that wealthy of company knowledge. In industries with a lot of turnover, that‚Äôs just going to be all the more valuable.

So far, OpenAI has yet to confirm for ChatGPT Connectors. And while TechCrunch reports that the feature should go into testing soon, we don‚Äôt yet have any kind of precise timetable.

https://www.zdnet.com/article/generative.title: Generative AI is finally finding its sweet spot, says Databricks chief AI scientist
https://www.zdnet.com/article/generative.body: As generative AI begins helping solve real-world problems, a new kind of data analytics is emerging, says Jonathan Frankle.
https://www.zdnet.com/article/generative.full_content:
If you strip away all the buzzwords aboutenterprise artificial intelligence,such as "agentic AI," the reality is that companies are learning what works in practice as they experiment with the technology, according to data tools giant Databricks.

Also:10 key reasons AI went mainstream overnight - and what happens next

"We're still learning where the right places are to put AI, where you can get the sweet spot of AI to help you solve a problem," said Databricks's chief AI scientist, Jonathan Frankle, in a recent interview he and I had in New York.

Databricks Chief AI scientist Jonathan Frankle.

On a basic level,generative AI, such as large language models, is making possible a new kind of enterprise analytics, said Frankle. Unstructured data, such as Word files, images, or videos, had no place in traditional data analytics before generative AI, noted Frankle. But now, it's a goldmine.

"Imagine tons and tons of unstructured documents, which are really tricky to analyze in a pre-generative AI or pre-LLM world, and suddenly you can extract meaningful features from them," he said. "Data that was useless in an analytics world is now incredibly valuable here."

Also:Will synthetic data derail generative AI's momentum or be the breakthrough we need?

While many people fixate on generative AI taking over actual programming code, a much simpler use would be to simply analyze a company's computer code.

"All the documentation for all of the code at your company" was "not really that useful as a data source in 2015, but, in 2025, incredibly valuable [...] just answering questions about your code for developers."

Similarly, "You can imagine every single chat log from a customer service application with real humans, doing high-level analytics on that. What is the average number of interactions in a conversation? What is the average time to resolve an issue? Things that would not have been possible ten years ago."

The role of data is central in developing generative AI apps, said Frankle. Frankle came to Databricks whenit bought the machine learning startuphe was working for, MosaicML, in 2023. MosaicML focuses on optimizing the infrastructure for running AI, whereas Databricks is one of the leading purveyors of data lakes and technology to move and shape data.

Also:AI agents aren't just assistants: How they're changing the future of work today

"The whole thesis for the acquisition was that we had one piece, Databricks had a lot of other pieces, and it made much more sense together," said Frankle.

"You're trying to deploy an AI customer service bot. What data is that customer service bot working off of?" Frankle explained. "It's working off of customer information, it's working off your documentation, it's working off your SQL databases. That's all on Databricks."

Having the data together in Databricks is the beginning of creating the kinds of new analytics Frankle cites. WhileLLMscan make use of a pile of unstructured data, it doesn't hurt to get a company's data into some kind of structure beforehand.

"If you did the work in advance to use an LLM to pre-process that data into some kind of structured form, like SQL or JSON, you're asking for less work on the part of the AI -- you should always try to make things as easy as possible for the AI because these systems are definitely not infallible."

Also:8 out of 10 college students and administrators welcome AI agents

An important preparatory step is putting the data into what are called "embeddings."

An "embedding model" is an AI model that is used to turn characters, words, or sentences into a vector -- a group of numbers -- that capture some of the semantic content of those characters, words, or sentences.

You can think of embeddings as numeric scores representing the relatedness of terms, such as "apple" to "fruit," or "baby" to "human."

Simple language models, even relatively small ones, such as Google's BERT from 2018, can be used to make embeddings. "You don't need huge models to get great embeddings," said Frankle.

A lot of embedding models have been developed in the open-source community, noted Frankle, by adapting Meta Platforms' Llama model via the process known as fine-tuning.

However, "You might need to train a custom embedding model," given that existing ones are "built on web data," making them very general.

In specific domains, such as healthcare, for example, a custom embedding model can find relationships between words and phrases better than a generic embedding model.

"We're finding that customizing embedding models can lead to disproportionately good retrieval improvement," said Frankle. "We think there's still a lot of juice to squeeze out of just making them [embedding models] more specific to a domain."

A well-developed embedding model is exceptionally important because "they will make the heavy lifting that's done [by the large language model] a lot easier," he said.

Also:Is your business AI-ready? 5 ways to avoid falling behind

Multiple embedding models can also be chained together, said Frankle. That can allow an AI model used in, for example, document search, to narrow down from a large group of a hundred documents to just a handful that answer a query.

In addition to tuning an embedding model, how data is fed into the embedding is its own area of excellence. "When you provide these documents to an embedding model, you usually don't want to provide the whole document all at once," he said.

"You often want to chunk it into pieces," and how to do so optimally is also a matter of experimenting and trying approaches.

Frankle added that Databricks is "doing research on all of these topics because, in a lot of cases, we don't think the state of the art is good enough," including embeddings.

While a lot can be "plug and play" via Databricks, says Frankle, "the trickiest part is there's still a lot of experimentation. There are a lot of knobs that need to be turned. Should you fine-tune, or should you not fine-tune? How many documents should you try to retrieve and put in the context? What is your chunk size?"

Beyond the techniques, knowing what apps to build is itself a journey and something of a fishing expedition.

"I think the hardest part in AI is having confidence that this will work," said Frankle. "If you came to me and said, 'Here's a problem in the healthcare space, here are the documents I have, do you think AI can do this?' my answer would be, 'Let's find out.'"

From what Frankle is seeing with customers, "Applications that are getting into practice right now tend to look for things that are a little more open-ended," he said -- meaning what the AI model produces can be fuzzy, not necessarily specific. "AI is great at producing an answer, not always great at producingtheanswer," he observed.

Also:Here's why you should ignore 99% of AI tools - and which four I use every day

"With AI, you can do fuzzy things, you can do document understanding in ways that I could never write a Python program for," Frankle explained.

"I also look for applications where it's relatively expensive to come to an answer but relatively cheap to check the answer." An example is the automatic generation of textual notes for a doctor from recordings of his patient exams. "A draft set of patient notes can be generated, they [the doctor or doctor's assistant] can check it, tweak a couple of things, and call it a day." That's a useful way to eliminate tedium, he said.

Conversely, "Applications where you need the right answer, and they're hard to check" may be something to avoid for now. He gave the example of drafting a legal document. "If the AI misses one thing, the human now needs to go and review the whole document to make sure they didn't miss anything else. So, what was the point of using the AI?" Frankle observed.

On the other hand, there is lots of potential for AI to do things such as take over grunt work for lawyers and paralegals and, as a result, broaden the access people have to lawyers.

Also:Want to win in the age of AI? You can either build it or build your business with it

"Suppose that AI could automate some of the most boring legal tasks that exist?" offered Frankle, whose parents are lawyers. "If you wanted an AI to help you do legal research, and help you ideate about how to solve a problem, or help you find relevant materials -- phenomenal!"

"We're still in very early days" of generative AI, "and so, kind of, we're benefiting from the strengths, but we're still learning how to mitigate the weaknesses."

In the midst of uncertainty, Frankle is impressed with how customers have quickly traversed the learning curve. "Two or three years ago, there was a lot of explaining to customers what generative AI was," he noted. "Now, when I talk to customers, they're using vector databases."

"These folks have a great intuition for where these things are succeeding and where they aren't," he said of Databricks customers.

Given that no company has an unlimited budget, Frankle advised starting with an initial prototype, so that investment only proceeds to the extent that it's clear an AI app will provide value.

Also:Even premium AI tools distort the news and fabricate links - these are the worst

"It should be something you can throw together in a day usingGPT-4, and a handful of documents you already have," he offered. The developer can enlist "a couple random people from around the company who can tell you you're on the right track here or not."

For managers, Frankle advises making exploration of generative AI a part of the job on a regular basis.

"People are motivated," such as data scientists, he noted. "It's even less about the money and more about just giving them the time and saying, as part of your job responsibilities, take a couple weeks, do a two-day hackathon, and just go see what you can do. That's really exciting for people."

The motto in enterprise generative AI might be, from tiny acorns grow mighty oaks.

As Frankle put it, "The person who happens to have that GPU in their basement, and is playing with Llama, actually is very sophisticated, and could be the generative AI expert of tomorrow."

https://www.forbes.com/advisor/banking/r.title: Revolut Review For 2025
https://www.forbes.com/advisor/banking/r.body: Revolut offers a savings account, prepaid cards to manage daily finances and investment accounts. Ideal for travelers and young people, Revolut makes it easy to convert money into different currencies,
https://www.forbes.com/advisor/banking/r.full_content:
Why you can trust Forbes Advisor

Our editors are committed to bringing you unbiased ratings and information.Advertisers do not and cannot influence our ratings.We use data-driven methodologies to evaluate financial products and companies, so that all are measured equally. You can read more about oureditorial guidelinesand thebanking methodologyfor the ratings below.

Revolut was launched in the United Kingdom in 2015 and has since grown to a global financial enterprise providing services to customers in 38 countries. More than 35 million consumers and 500,000 business customers use Revolut‚Äôs financial products, including its money management and investing platform, prepaid cards, andsavings accounts.

Revolut is a digital company with no local branches to visit, but 24/7 customer support is available via in-app chat. Unfortunately, only Ultra Premium members can speak with a customer representative on the phone, and only UK customers can obtain Ultra Premium accounts. U.S. Customers have no telephone support options.

Revolut also doesn‚Äôt personally hold your funds; instead, money put into your savings account is held at Sutton Bank and is covered byFDIC insuranceup to $250,000.

Revolut offers a savings account, prepaid cards, and investing services. Different plan tiers, from Standard to Metal, have their own features and perks‚Äîand monthly fees.

Each plan offered by Revolut includes aspects of both checking and savings accounts. However, it‚Äôs important to note that Revolut is not a traditional bank and does not offer separate checking and savings accounts. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about Revolut‚Äôs account options.

Revolut does not offer separate checking and savings accounts. Instead, it offers a savings account with a prepaid card for daily financial management. There are three account tiers, two of which come with fees. Here are the accounts available.

Here are the features of Revolut‚Äôs standard account:

The premium account offers all of the benefits of Revolut‚Äôs standard account, plus some additional perks. Here the the key features of Revolut‚Äôs premium account:

Metal offers everything the standard and premium accounts do, along with these additional features:

Revolut doesn‚Äôt offer certificates of deposit (CDs), money market accounts, credit cards or loans, but it does provide investing services. You can purchase cryptocurrencies, commodities and stocks with Revolut. More than 210 crypto tokens can be traded. You can also purchase commodities, including gold, silver, platinum and palladium, or trade more than 2,000 stocks commission-free.

Revolut is a mobile-first platform. You‚Äôll need the app to sign up, manage your funds, send and receive payments and use other Revolut features. Revolut currently has 4.7 out of 5 stars on the iOS store and 4.5 stars on the Google Play store. The app allows you to make payments in more than 25 currencies, send funds instantly with a click, and connect with customer support.

Like Revolut, Wise is a multi-currency account that allows you to hold and convert dozens of currencies and move money across the globe. Revolut currently supports fewer currencies than Wise, although more currencies are coming.

Like Revolut, Chime offers mobile-first banking and a card that works for payments worldwide. However, Chime accounts can only be opened by U.S. customers with a valid Social Security number, while Revolut offers services to customers across the globe.

Chime is mostly fee-free, except for withdrawals made from out-of-network ATMs. Revolut, on the other hand, charges users for many advanced services, including withdrawals above monthly limits.

Chime also offers faster access to your paychecks, up to two days early, and has a much better Better Business Bureau Rating and more positive online customer reviews than Revolut.

Schwab Bank Investor checking offers investing and banking services, just as Revolut does‚Äîalthough you must be a Schwab investment customer to gain access to the checking account.

Schwab offers its Investor Checking customers unlimited ATM fee rebates worldwide and no foreign transaction fees. Like Revolut, it has a full-featured mobile app to manage many banking services.

Schwab does not have the focus on international customers and travel perks Revolut does. But it provides more traditional banking services‚Äîincluding access to loans and other financial products‚Äîand has local branches you can visit for customer support.

Forbes Advisor scores banks and credit unions on a number of factors, including the following:

We give separate ratings to the individual products offered by each financial institution, such as checking accounts, savings accounts, money market accounts and CDs. We assign banks a rating from one and five stars, with one star being the lowest rating and five stars being the highest.

To learn about our rating system and review methodology, check out our guide onhow Forbes Advisor reviews banks.

Revolut does not offer all of the features you‚Äôd expect from a standard bank, such as access to certificates of deposit. Customers will have to pay fees if they want more advanced features, and there is no in-person or phone customer support in the United States.

Revolut is a legitimate business that has been operating since 2015. It has more than 50 million customers across over 140 countries and regions. Users have given the Revolut app stellar ratings, but the business lacks Better Business Bureau accreditation and reviews there are mixed. But Revolut‚Äôs partner bank in the U.S. is FDIC-insured, so your deposited funds are protected up to the $250,000 FDIC limit.

Yes, Revolut works in the United States. It debuted its financial services for Americans in March 2020 and reported in October 2023 that it had 840,000 customers in the U.S.

https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/loca.title: Memphis City Council gives final approval on selling property to xAI for water reuse plant
https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/loca.body: The Memphis City Council Tuesday evening gave final approval on selling 13 acres of land where xAI is expected to build a water reuse facility.
https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/loca.full_content:
The Memphis City Council Tuesday evening gave final approval on selling 13 acres of land to an affiliate ofElon Musk's xAI company.

Awater reuse plantwill be built on the property, neighboring the T.E. Maxon Water Treatment facility. The facility is expected toreduce strain on the Memphis Sand aquiferby 9%.

The Tennessee Valley Authority's Allen Combined Cycle Plant and Nucor Steel‚Äôs Memphis plant will also use the water treated at the new facility in addition to xAI's data center. The water reuse facility is anticipated to cost $80 million to build.

The council approved the sale during its Feb. 18 meeting but had to vote on it a second time Tuesday. ACity of Memphis ordinancerequires two votes on property sales over $20,000. CTC Property LLC, an affiliate of xAI that bought the land, agreed to pay $820,000 for the 13 acres.

Tuesday's vote saw nine councilmembers vote in favor of the sale. Councilwoman Yolanda Cooper-Sutton voted against it ‚Äî citing her support for the water reuse facility, but concern over residents not having their questions answered ‚Äî and Councilwoman Rhonda Logan abstained from the vote.

Multipleresidents from Boxtown and South Memphis voiced concernsover the speed with which Musk and xAI were moving in Memphis and the lack of community input. Others also said they were worried about the impact of using natural gas turbines to power the supercomputer.

Boxtown and Westwood, two communities south of xAI's data facility, have experienced decades of air pollution from the industries near the neighborhoods.

"This affects people," executive director for Memphis Community Against Pollution KeShaun Pearson said during public comment Thursday. "The people have been excluded. Something that [Councilman] JB Smiley [Jr.] said before is that 'We are all here to move the community forward, and in order to move the community forward, we have to include the community.' These people have to be included in the decisions that are being made."
